articles.headline: Dream of Buying a Home Gets Harder for Single Mothers
articles.snippet: Lost pay during the pandemic and high costs threaten strides they had made in homeownership, often a key driver of long-term wealth.
articles.abstract: Lost pay during the pandemic and high costs threaten strides they had made in homeownership, often a key driver of long-term wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karlet Hewitt decided to make major lifestyle changes after experiencing the shocks of the pandemic: the income hit, the confinement, the view of the padlocked park through her third-floor apartment window. In February, Ms. Hewitt — a single mother to a 9-year-old boy — left Mount Vernon, N.Y., and headed south.

articles.headline: Substitute Teachers Never Got Much Respect, but Now They Are in Demand
articles.snippet: Because of staff shortages, some school districts are canceling classes. Others are lowering their hiring standards. The result can be a chaotic classroom.
articles.abstract: Because of staff shortages, some school districts are canceling classes. Others are lowering their hiring standards. The result can be a chaotic classroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Amber McCoy called in sick this fall, there was not a substitute teacher who could step into her fourth-grade class in Huntington, W.Va.

articles.headline: The White House Says Its Plans Will Slow Inflation. The Big Question Is: When?
articles.snippet: The Biden administration has argued that its infrastructure and broader economic package will slow rapid price increases. But that will take time.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration has argued that its infrastructure and broader economic package will slow rapid price increases. But that will take time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rocketing inflation has become a headache for U.S. consumers, and President Biden has a go-to prescription. He says a key way to help relieve increasing prices is to pass a $1.85 trillion collection of spending programs and tax cuts that is currently languishing in the Senate.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: The Bolsonaro-Trump Connection Threatening Brazil’s Elections
articles.snippet: With his poll numbers falling, President Jair Bolsonaro is already questioning the legitimacy of next year’s election. He has help from the United States.
articles.abstract: With his poll numbers falling, President Jair Bolsonaro is already questioning the legitimacy of next year’s election. He has help from the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The conference hall was packed, with a crowd of more than 1,000 cheering attacks on the press, the liberals and the politically correct. There was Donald Trump Jr. warning that the Chinese could meddle in the election, a Tennessee congressman who voted against certifying the 2020 vote, and the president complaining about voter fraud.

articles.headline: Project Veritas and the Line Between Journalism and Political Spying
articles.snippet: Documents show how the conservative group worked with lawyers to gauge how far its deceptive reporting practices could go before running afoul of federal laws.
articles.abstract: Documents show how the conservative group worked with lawyers to gauge how far its deceptive reporting practices could go before running afoul of federal laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after F.B.I. agents searched the homes of two former Project Veritas operatives last week, James O’Keefe, the leader of the conservative group, took to YouTube to defend its work as “the stuff of responsible, ethical journalism.”
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Migrants in Peril, and Raw Emotions, in a Volatile European Border Standoff
articles.snippet: A confrontation over migrants between Belarus and Poland is growing more volatile, as nationalist fervor rises in both countries and a humanitarian disaster looms.
articles.abstract: A confrontation over migrants between Belarus and Poland is growing more volatile, as nationalist fervor rises in both countries and a humanitarian disaster looms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Thousands of migrants, unwilling weapons in a geopolitical struggle, in peril in a freezing border zone. Far-right nationalists marching on the streets of Warsaw, calling for harsh action against asylum seekers. Belligerent national leaders facing off across a razor-wire border.

articles.headline: 275 Minutes on Hold: Why Airline Customer Service Still Can’t Keep Up
articles.snippet: It’s been a familiar and infuriating story during the pandemic: Hours waiting for an agent only to have the call dropped. The ordeal of rescheduling canceled flights. Delayed refunds. What gives?
articles.abstract: It’s been a familiar and infuriating story during the pandemic: Hours waiting for an agent only to have the call dropped. The ordeal of rescheduling canceled flights. Delayed refunds. What gives?
articles.lead_paragraph: After Southwest Airlines canceled his family’s flight on Oct. 9, Tyler Reece Maness realized that his best option was to drive 18 hours from Oklahoma City to Orlando, Fla. That’s the only way his 7-year-old daughter would make it to Boo Bash, Disney World’s $159-a-person Halloween event, the following night.

articles.headline: Now TV Wants Nielsen to Measure Up
articles.snippet: After years of complaints, NBCUniversal and its peers are looking for other ways to count viewers, with or without the ratings giant.
articles.abstract: After years of complaints, NBCUniversal and its peers are looking for other ways to count viewers, with or without the ratings giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: TV executives have been complaining about Nielsen for years, saying their shows have more viewers than they get credit for. They have also claimed that Nielsen, the 98-year-old research firm whose name is practically synonymous with TV ratings, uses antiquated technology that hasn’t kept up with viewers who have moved away from cable and network TV.

articles.headline: What Bosses Really Think About the Future of the Office
articles.snippet: C.E.O.s are eager for employees to return — and afraid of alienating those who have grown accustomed to working from home.
articles.abstract: C.E.O.s are eager for employees to return — and afraid of alienating those who have grown accustomed to working from home.
articles.lead_paragraph: People think about the office differently now — including the C.E.O.s who for so long kept a watchful eye on which workers were at their desks.

articles.headline: Hong Kong Broadcaster’s Swift Turn From Maverick Voice to Official Mouthpiece
articles.snippet: RTHK has often set the news agenda with its aggressive coverage of the city. But a Beijing clampdown has changed that, with pro-China coverage filling the void.
articles.abstract: RTHK has often set the news agenda with its aggressive coverage of the city. But a Beijing clampdown has changed that, with pro-China coverage filling the void.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Not long after Patrick Li took over as the government-appointed director of Hong Kong’s public broadcaster, a digital lock pad appeared outside his office entrance.

articles.headline: As Holidays Near, Bosses Try to Coax Vietnam’s Workers Back to Factories
articles.snippet: Vietnam, one of the world’s largest suppliers of apparel and footwear, is experiencing a labor shortage. Many employees are reluctant to return after a harsh summer lockdown.
articles.abstract: Vietnam, one of the world’s largest suppliers of apparel and footwear, is experiencing a labor shortage. Many employees are reluctant to return after a harsh summer lockdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thu Trang traveled to Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, in 2019, ecstatic to get a job at a factory. She worked eight-hour shifts and was guaranteed overtime pay, and the wages were nearly triple what she had made as a farmer back home.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Vo Kieu Bao Uyen
